Title: Some Spotify Users Can Now Personalize Their Algorithm
Description:
The new AI-powered "Prompted Playlist" feature will be available in beta to Spotify's premium users in New Zealand on Thursday (Dec. 11).


													By
												

	Kristin Robinson


Senior Writer


	On Wednesday (Dec. 10), Spotify announced it will now allow users to personalize their algorithm. 


	“Imagine a Spotify that doesn't just passively learn from you but literally listens to you,” a company blog post reads. “For the first time, your ideas, your logic and your creativity can actually power the Spotify algorithm, directing how it thinks, adapts and responds to you.”


	As part of the rollout, the blog post introduces a feature called the “Prompted Playlist,” which will first roll out in beta to premium users in New Zealand on Thursday (Dec. 11.) Essentially, this lets users use AI to generate a playlist — a similar concept to Spotify's recent integration with ChatGPT to allow for prompt-based music and podcast recommendations.ree


	“You could ask for ‘music from my top artists from the last five years,' then push it further with ‘and feature deep cuts I haven't heard yet,'” the blog post continues. “Or you could request ‘high-energy pop and hip-hop for a 30-minute 5K run that keeps a steady pace before easing into relaxing songs for a cool-down,' and layer on something like ‘include music from this year's biggest films and most-talked-about TV shows that match my taste.' You choose how broad or specific you want to go.”


	From there, users can “fine-tune the results by editing the prompt or start fresh whenever you want.” Each song included in the playlist will include descriptions and context to tell the user why Spotify selected that song, “so the playlist feels alive and crafted specifically for your prompt and your taste.”


	This can refresh on a periodic basis — daily or weekly — and Spotify refers to the feature as a way to “curate your next Discover Weekly.” For those who don't know what to prompt, there will be an “ideas” button that helps select prompts for the user. 


	News of the feature arrives just weeks after Instagram announced the launch of a somewhat similar feature, allowing “for you to tune your algorithm on Instagram by adding and removing topics based on your interests,” Instagram CEO Adam Mosseri wrote on Threads.


	The Spotify blog post says this launch “is just the beginning of a new phase [of Spotify] where listeners take the lead and make even more of every minute,” noting that there's more to come in 2026.

Title: Taylor Swift Asked to Name Her Five Favorite of Her Own Songs on ‘Colbert': ‘This Is So Much Pressure'
Description:
Swift's No. 1 choice is an epic song.


													By
												

	Lars Brandle



Taylor Swift either has too many, or not enough songs. Or simply, not enough spare time.


	When Swift dropped by The Late Show With Stephen Colbert on Wednesday night, Dec. 10, the outgoing host asked the pop superstar to name her top five songs from her catalog. Tough call, even for Swift.


	With that quiz, Swift joined the esteemed company of Dolly Parton, Elton John, Paul Simon and Bruce Springsteen. All of them are inducted into the Rock And Roll Hall of Fame. For Swift, it's just a matter of time before she gets the Rock Hall call.

	












	
	
		
					Related		
	


















	
	
		
					Therapy, Meds and Visits to the Beach: Comeback Kid Lewis Capaldi Talks Lifestyle Changes		
	






















	
	
		
					Taylor Swift Says 'Hey Stephen' to Colbert in Cute Backstage Video Ahead of 'Late Show' Visit		
	






















	
	
		
					Kenshi Yonezu's 'IRIS OUT' Returns to No. 1 as Number_i's 'LAVALAVA' Bows as No. 2 on Japan Hot 100		
	













	
	
		
					Explore		
	





















	
		
					Taylor Swift		
					





See latest videos, charts and news



See latest videos, charts and news


	Swift, however, struggled to complete her task. “This is so much pressure,” she told the Colbert. “You're already writing five.”


	Party pooper alert: the “Shake It Off” singer requested a “little time to get back to” Colbert for the definitive list. “Because I don't have enough, see,” she continued. “I think I require a little bit of time to like, appreciate my work in a way… and it's constantly changing, right. It's a little too soon.”


	Swift was able to select her first choice, “All Too Well,” the 10-minute version, which was released as part of the re-recorded Red (Taylor's Version) from November 2021.


	“I'm really obsessed with The Life of a Showgirl right now, the whole album,” she noted.


	Swift also selected “Mirrorball” from 2020's Folklore album, but admitted she “can't really do any of the others.” 

	











	Given some time, “we could do an update at some point,” Swift asked.


	Colbert, with the type of delivery that was so sharp and fast, he could hurt a person, remarked: “You've got all the time you need between now and May.” That timeframe is a firm one, after which the award-winning host is set to be taken off CBS' airwaves.


	Watch Taylor Swift's top 5 challenge with Stephen Colbert below. 


	For her first return to The Late Show since 2021, Swift made an adorable TikTok video with Colbert backstage.


	As previously reported, the clip begins with a close-up of Swift in a fuzzy winter jacket vibing to the humming intro of her 2008 Fearless album cut “Hey Stephen.” When the camera pans out, we see that the host is there too, and he even lip-syncs the first word of the song: “Yeah.” Swift then breaks her so-far straight face to give a big goofy smile and wave at the funnyman and mouth, “Hey, Stephen!”


The Late Show beamed out Wednesday night at 11:35 p.m. ET on CBS and streaming on Paramount+.

Title: Disney Inks Blockbuster $1B Deal With OpenAI, Handing Characters Over To Sora
Description:
By Jake Kanter 

International Investigations Editor


Disney has put its chips in on AI.


	The Hollywood giant has signed a major deal with OpenAI, investing $1B in the artificial intelligence giant and handing over characters from Frozen and Star Wars to generative AI video app Sora.


	It is comfortably the most significant collaboration between a Hollywood studio and an AI company to date, and suggests Disney has taken the view: if you can't beat them, join them.


	The three-year licensing agreement will allow Sora users to create bespoke fan videos with the likes of Captain America, Yoda, and Moana. A selection of these videos will stream on Disney+, which the company hinted at during an earnings call last month.

	











	Sora 2, the most sophisticated iteration of the app, caused outrage among rights holders when it launched in October. It adopted an opt-out policy, meaning IP was usable on the app until a rights holder issued a removal request. 




			Watch on Deadline		







	Disney is now opting in — and in a big way. It is the first major content licensing partner on Sora, which enables users to create short-form videos with text prompts.


	Disney will also become a major OpenAI customer, using its tech to build new products, tools, and experiences, including for Disney+, and deploying ChatGPT for its employees. The deal does not, however, allow OpenAI to train its machine learning models on Disney IP.


	Disney CEO Bob Iger said: “Technological innovation has continually shaped the evolution of entertainment, bringing with it new ways to create and share great stories with the world.

	











	“The rapid advancement of artificial intelligence marks an important moment for our industry, and through this collaboration with OpenAI we will thoughtfully and responsibly extend the reach of our storytelling through generative AI, while respecting and protecting creators and their works. 


	“Bringing together Disney's iconic stories and characters with OpenAI's groundbreaking technology puts imagination and creativity directly into the hands of Disney fans in ways we've never seen before, giving them richer and more personal ways to connect with the Disney characters and stories they love.”


	Sam Altman, co-founder and CEO of OpenAI, added: “This agreement shows how AI companies and creative leaders can work together responsibly to promote innovation that benefits society, respect the importance of creativity, and help works reach vast new audiences.”


	Disney characters available to use on Sora will include Mickey Mouse, Minnie Mouse, Lilo, Stitch, Ariel, Belle, Beast, Cinderella, Baymax, Simba, Mufasa, as well as characters from the worlds of Encanto, Frozen, Inside Out, Moana, Monsters Inc., Toy Story, Up, Zootopia, and many more.


	Also featured will be animated or illustrated versions of Marvel and Lucasfilm characters like Black Panther, Captain America, Deadpool, Groot, Iron Man, Loki, Thor, Thanos, Darth Vader, Han Solo, Luke Skywalker, Leia, the Mandalorian, Stormtroopers, Yoda, and more.


	What appears to be off the table is exploiting the performances of actors, with the press release noting that Disney and OpenAI will “respect the rights of individuals to appropriately control the use of their voice and likeness.”


	The release added: “OpenAI and Disney have affirmed a shared commitment to maintaining robust controls to prevent the generation of illegal or harmful content.”

Title: ‘Supergirl' Trailer Takes Off: Watch Milly Alcock As Kara Zor-El
Description:
By Anthony D'Alessandro 

Editorial Director/Box Office Editor


	It's finally here, the first trailer for Warner Bros DC Studios‘ next big summer movie, Supergirl, starring House of Dragon‘s Milly Alcock in the title role as Superman's cousin — who has a drinking problem. 


	Fans caught a glimpse of Alcock as Supergirl at the end of James Gunn's Superman when she stumbles into the Man of Steel's fortress of solitude. In the trailer, it looks like Kara would have no problem living in the same colorful, ragtag gang universe as Gunn's Guardians of the Galaxy. What's clear here is that Kara isn't a carbon copy of Superman ala Supergirl in the 1984 movie; she has her own personal demons. Not only does she have the grit to take on any Mad Max type who comes her way, but what sets her apart from Kal-El?

	











	“He sees the good in everyone, and I see the truth,” she emphasizes in the trailer here. 




			Watch on Deadline		







	Superman's dog Krypto is along for the adventure. 


	The movie, directed by Craig Gillespie, is based on the Tom King's 2022 comic book series Supergirl: Woman of Tomorrow, which Bilquis Evely illustrated, and Ana Nogueira adapted the comic book for the big screen. In the comic, Supergirl and young alien girl Knolle travel across the galaxy to hunt Krem of the Yellow Hill after he kills Knolle's father in cold blood. It's been billed among fans as being akin to the John Wayne classic, True Grit. 


Supergirl happens in theaters on June 26, 2026.

Title: Tyler Perry's 'Beauty In Black' Renewed For Third & Final Season At Prime Video
Description:
By Armando Tinoco 

Staff Writer

Kimmie's journey is coming to an end on Beauty in Black as Netflix has renewed the Tyler Perry series for a third and final season.

The streamer also announced that the eigh episodes from Season 2, Part 2 of the series, starring Taylor Polidore Williams, will premiere on March 19, 2026.

Premiering in 2024, the drama series spent seven weeks ranked in the Top 10 and, by its second week, was at the top of the list in 28 countries, according to Netflix. Part 1 of Season 1 also topped the most-watched list in 14 countries during its second week.

RELATED: ‘Avatar: The Last Airbender' Season 2 Trailer & Photos: First Look At Netflix Live-Action Series

Beauty in Black was created, directed, written, and executive produced by Perry. The series follows two women leading very different lives. While Kimmie (Taylor Polidore Williams) struggles to make a living after her mother kicked her out, Mallory (Crystle Stewart) runs a successful business. They are entangled in each other's lives.

In Season 2, the ruthless, backstabbing family behind a beauty brand — and an underground trafficking ring — will face a reckoning. Kimmie, the once-unassuming sex worker in their employ, becomes an unstoppable force of vengeance on a mission to rescue her kidnapped sister.

Beauty in Black also stars Amber Reign Smith, Xavier Smalls, Ricco Ross, Julian Horton, Steven G. Norfleet, Richard Lawson, Terrell Carter, Bryan Tanaka, Charles Malik Whitfield, and Debbi Morgan. Title: Disney Fires Off Cease-And-Desist Letter To Google Over AI Services
Description:
By Ted Johnson 

Political Editor


The Walt Disney Co. has fired off a cease-and-desist letter to Google, claiming that its AI training models and services infringe on its copyrights on a “massive scale.”


	The letter was sent on Wednesday, just before the company made the announcement that it has reached an agreement with a Google rival, OpenAI, to provide its characters and IP for use in the latter company's services.


	Disney contended that Google's “willful infringement is especially alarming because it is leveraging its dominance in generative AI and across multiple other markets to make its infringing AI Services as widely available as possible.”

	











	“Google is intentionally amplifying the scope of its infringement, by making its infringing AI Services available across so many channels to so many consumers, flooding the market with infringing works, and reaping enormous profits and other value from its unlawful, harmful, and damaging exploitation of Disney's copyrighted works,” per the letter from David Singer, the Jenner & Block attorney representing Disney.




			Watch on Deadline		







RELATED: Bob Iger Weighs In With Concerns Over Netflix “Pricing Leverage Over The Consumer” If Streamer Snags Warner Bros. Streaming & Studio Assets


	Disney previously sent cease-and-desist letters to Meta and Character.AI, and is part of litigation with NBCUniversal and Warner Bros. Discovery against Midjourney and Minimax. 


	A Google spokesperson did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

	











	In the letter, Disney claims that Google “has refused to implement any technological measures to mitigate or prevent copyright infringement, even though such measures are readily available and being used by Google's competitors.” The letter adds that Disney has tried to engage Google “for months,” but the tech giant has “done nothing” and the use of its copyrighted works “has only increased” during that period.


	The letter alleges that not only has Disney IP been distributed without authorization in AI services but that Google has copied “a large corpus” of copyrighted works in training models. The letter cites models including Veo, Imagen and Nano Banana.


	Disney's letter also cited the ability of uses to generate images and videos via text prompts, including Star Wars characters, Marvel characters, Pixar works, classic animated characters and The Simpsons, among other IP.


	“Google operates as a virtual vending machine, capable of reproducing, rendering, and distributing copies of Disney's valuable library of copyrighted characters and other works on a mass scale,” The letter states. “And compounding Google's blatant infringement, many of the infringing images generated by Google's AI Services are branded with Google's Gemini logo, falsely implying that Google's exploitation of Disney's intellectual property is authorized and endorsed by Disney.”


	The letter also pointed to Google Gemini, its primary brand, and claimed that it “is treating Disney's valuable copyrighted characters like its own and making them available to subscribers for a fee.” Disney included the images of Simba and Nala from The Lion King and of Darth Vader that it said were generated by a “simple prompt.” The letter also cited Google use of its AI across its businesses, including YouTube and mobile apps.


	The letter called on Google to cease further copying and distribution of Disney IP in its AI services, as well as to implement technical measures to “ensure that no further outputs” infringe on the company's works. Disney also called on Google to identify which copyrighted works it has used to train its AI models, and to cease any use of them for such purpose.


	AI companies have argued that the use of copyrighted material, particularly in training models, is a “fair use,” a concept that is being litigated in the courts.


	The timing of the letter, just as the company announced its agreement with OpenAI, appeared to be no coincidence. A source familiar with Disney executives' thinking said, “Our agreement with OpenAI demonstrates that the world of AI does not have to be lawless, and that technology innovators and creative industries can work together and thrive if they are willing to respect the value of creators and their works.”

Title: Taylor Swift live updates: Pop star reveals she was sick multiple times during Eras Tour — and why canceling shows wasn't an option
Description: Follow Taylor Swift live updates from Page Six for peeks into her relationship with fiancé Travis Kelce, the latest on her upcoming docuseries, “The End of an Era,” and new album, “The Life of a Showgirl” — plus news, fan theories and more.

Title: Bill de Blasio's ex Nomiki Konst claims former mayor wanted kids with her before cheating scandal
Description:
Bill de Blasio's ex Nomiki Konst said he wanted to have a child with her before he cheated on her with Arizona mayor Roxanna Valenzuela.

Konst dropped the bombshell during her appearance on the YouTube show “Why Did They Break Up?”. 

The political commentator, 41, shared that she has Endometriosis and underwent six rounds of egg freezing. She said she brought this up with de Blasio, 64, and that he was not only “open” to the conversation about the possibility of having children with her, he actually asked her lots of questions about it.

Advertisement

“On that flight to California, we talked the entire time about the process and what it would be like, we just got pretty serious very quickly,” she recalled.

Advertisement

When host Touré asked her, “He wanted to have a child with you?,” she replied, “Yes.”

But a source told Page Six that Konst and de Blasio weren't trying to have children together, despite her freezing her eggs.

Sources dropped details to Page Six about the former New York City mayor's headline-making affair with Valenzuela, specifically, how it began. De Blasio and Valenzuela began seeing each other more than a month before he split from Konst, whom he dated for nearly a year.

Advertisement


							Start your day with Page Six Daily.						




						Please provide a valid email.					



				By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy.			


					Want celebrity news as it breaks?				

The politicians first met for a business lunch in September, then the pair went back to his apartment to have sex hours later, a source told us.

Two days later, the two had another tryst when the South Tucson mayor took him to volunteer at a soup kitchen.

Advertisement

De Blasio came clean to Konst about the affair while they were on a vacation in Greece when she was in the midst of a round of IVF for egg freezing, a source said.

Still, a source close to Konst told us that she and de Blasio attempted to work it out. But we're told that on Nov. 4, she “learned he was still talking to Roxanna and [Roxanna] was coming to NYC [to see him] while they were walking into Zohran Mamdani's election night victory party.”

De Blasio is still dating Valenzuela, 41, and tells Page Six that he “fell in love” with her.

“I wish Nomiki well and I'm sorry for how our relationship ended,” he told us. “I fell in love with someone else and I should have told her sooner. I'm now in a wonderful relationship with Roxanna Valenzuela that we will continue to nurture and keep private.”

De Blasio has two children with Chirlane McCray, who formerly identified as a lesbian. The pair separated in 2023 and do not intend to divorce.

Title: Taylor Swift visits ‘The Late Show With Stephen Colbert' in maroon velvet minidress
Description:
So scarlet, it was maroon.

Taylor Swift was dressed in her festive best for a visit to “The Late Show with Stephen Colbert” Wednesday night to promote her upcoming Disney+ docuseries, “The End of an Era.”

The “Life of a Showgirl” singer wore a burgundy velvet David Koma dress with a sculptural off-the-shoulder silhouette, along with matching Aquazzura pumps in the same lush fabric.

Swift kept the cranberry color palette going with her elegant diamond-and-ruby necklace, and finished her late-night look with a delicate opal bracelet.

The superstar's latest outfit is right in line with her “Showgirl” aesthetic, marked by luxe materials and Vegas-worthy sparkle. 

Whether in the spotlight to promote her own projects or in the stands cheering on her fiancé, NFL tight end Travis Kelce, Swift is dressing to impress and inspire.

On Sunday, the “Honey” singer wore a holiday-ready herringbone Miu Miu jacket to cheer on the Chiefs at Arrowhead Stadium. While the team ultimately lost to the Houston Texans, Swift and her longtime “squad” members, Selena Gomez and Lena Dunham, were on hand to provide moral support to the Kansas City crew.

As for what's next in Swift's wild week?

Following the debut of the first two episodes of “The End of an Era” on Friday, Swift will ring in her 36th birthday on Saturday, hopefully surrounded by the three Fs: friends, family and fiancé.

But there's no sleep for Swifties this weekend — and that includes your favorite Page Swift editors, too.

The birthday girl will likely continue the party back in Kansas City when the Chiefs face the Los Angeles Chargers on their home turf. 

Here's hoping “Colbert” helped the singing superstar warm up for this busy weekend of revelry — and that Swift has time to rest up for her big, bridal year in 2026.

Title: ‘Survivor' Season 49 Week 12 Live Recap & Spoilers
Description:
The “Survivor” season 49 finale is one week away, which means these castaways are feeling even more pressure to survive Tribal Council tonight. The votes were unanimous last week on “Survivor” 2025, but that probably won't happen again tonight when Jeff Probst reveals the “Survivor” results. It's time for another week of challenges and backstabbing, but who gets voted off “Survivor” 49 tonight? Find out during our “Survivor” season 49 live recap below!

Just six castaways are remaining on “Survivor” season 49. They know the finale is coming up, so they know they have to make moves now before it's too late. Soph talked about this last week, but she is back at it again tonight, as seen in the sneak peek video from CBS. She wants to go against Savannah or Rizo, but then voted out Sophie last week.

She is trying to plot with Sage and Kristina this week, but will the plan go through this week? We made our predictions earlier, but find out tonight and find out who got eliminated on “Survivor” season 49 during our “Survivor” live recap below.

WARNING: SPOILERS AHEAD: THIS LIVE RECAP WILL BE UPDATED THROUGHOUT THE EPISODE, SO DO NOT KEEP READING IF YOU DO NOT WANT TO READ SPOILERS.

KEEP REFRESHING THE PAGE FOR THE LATEST “SURVIVOR” LIVE RECAP UPDATES.

The castaways are back from Tribal Council, and spirits are high. They all came together to get Sophie out, so no tension tonight. Steven is happy, since he still gets to keep his Block a Vote advantage. Then Soph says she'd like the be called Sophie now!

Here we are, another week, another Tribal Council, and Rizo still has his idol. He told everyone it expires at the final six, so he would have to use it tonight. However, it actually expires at the final five, so he can keep it with them all thinking he's going to play it tonight.

The next day arrives, and it's a rainy day. We are back with Soph talking about how she needs to go after Savannah and Rizo. She is trying to plant seeds about this.

The castaways meet Jeff, and it's day 22. For this challenge, they will race through obstacles to gather three bags. They will then try to land a sandbag on top of a tall pole. The winner gets a Mexican feast, featuring margaritas and desserts. They will also get a night at the Sanctuary, including letters from home!

Steven is the first to gather his bags. He then finds his color sandbag, so he gets started. They all get their sandbag and start tossing. Everyone is close, but no one is getting. Finally, Savannah lands her sandbag, and she wins this challenge. She gets to bring two people with her. She picks Rizo (who was crying earlier at the mention of letters) and Soph, so she sticks with her alliance.

Spirits are high at the reward, as these three are planning on a Final 3 together. They say they will be best friends after this ends. However, we all know they are going to stab each other in the back eventually.

Meanwhile, the other tribe members are back at camp and not happy to lose. Sage thinks it's karma that Savannah won and for not getting her out when she wanted to a couple of weeks ago. Kristina said Soph is ready to get Savannah out, but this reward might change her mind. Then Steven tells them about his advantage, which he says would give them a majority.

At the reward, they seem to solidify that they are a Final 3 and name themselves the Tres Leches alliance. Then Soph tells them about her Knowledge is Power advantage. Now they say she can steal Steven's advantage and then get him out.

The winners then enjoy their family letters from home. They said it's exactly what they needed, and it gives them a boost. Of course, Rizo is a hot mess when reading his. Each letter makes him cry even more.

Meanwhile, back at camp, the losers are trying to sleep. They have a special rat visitor, and Sage is over it all.

The next day arrives, and it's awkward. Rizo tries to talk with Steven, but it all seems to come down to the next Immunity Challenge and who wins that.

For this challenge, the castaways will put one foot on the end of a hinged beam. At the end of the beam is a ball. They will use that one foot to keep the ball on the beam. The ball falls off, and they are out of the challenge. The last one with their ball on the beam wins immunity and a spot in next week's finale.

They did this challenge in season 45. The winner of that challenge went on to win the season! That challenge lasted 24 minutes. 

For tonight, the sun is shining bright, so it's hot. Then the wind is coming, to mess with them some. Rizo is out pretty fast. Then we see Soph drop her ball. Kristina is struggling, and her ball finally drops. It's been three minutes, and three castaways are out.

Steven is struggling also, and he finally slips and his ball drops, so he is out. Now, Savannah starts running her mouth again, as it's down to her and Sage. She says it's just friendly banter.

They then make it to 24 minutes, so they are lasting longer tonight. Now the talk starts, as Sage wants Savannah to drop. She says she wants it and will keep Savannah safe tonight. It doesn't work, as neither is dropping.

They both started struggling, but Sage was really struggling. They make it over 35 minutes, but Sage finally drops, and Savannah wins immunity tonight. Emotions are high as Sage gets a lot of love.

Back at camp, Tres Leches wants to get Steven out, of course. Then Rizo talks with Steven, who says he will be going after Soph since Savannah has immunity, and they think Rizo has to play the idol.

Then Rizo talks with Sage, saying they should go after Steven, and that would help her win. Sage is thinking Steven could be a good vote, as she wants it to be her, Kristina, and Soph at the end. Kristina tries to get them to go after Soph.

Now Kristina talks with Steven, and slips about Steven being a target. He is not happy and vents to Sage about it. The Tres Leches thinks they are safe, as Soph will play her advantage to take Steven's advantage. However, then Soph is contemplating things, as they don't know what Steven's advantage is. She could take Rizo's idol and guarantee she is safe.

Steven says he has played his advantage, and he is using it to block Savannah's vote.

The castaways are in place, and this is supposed to be a jaw-dropping night, so what will it bring? The night starts with talk about Savannah's reward and who she took with her. What the talk was when both sides were gone. Rizo says the side that comes out on top of this vote might control the rest of this game.

Before the vote takes place, Soph speaks up, and she says she has the Knowledge is Power advantage. She says she wants to take the advantage from Steven, but he says he doesn't have one! What? He could have played it before, or did he give it to someone else? At the vote, we see Savannah's vote is blocked, so he did play it early! Soph is pissed at Steven, but she did it to herself.

Results – Jeff tallies the votes and Rizo makes another speech, but keeps the idol again! The votes: Steven, Soph, Steven, and Steven. The jury is shocked, as everyone is shocked. Sage says she couldn't have beat him. They just handed that one to Tres Leches.

What do you think of the results on “Survivor” season 49 tonight?

This survivor is the most boring one on record for me.  Stupid play tonight.

Title: ‘Survivor' Star Opens Up About Close Friendship With Fellow Contestant
Description:
Season 49 “Survivor” contestant Sophie Segreti has spoken about her close friendship with fellow player Sage Ahrens-Nichols and how the pair have mended their relationship since leaving the island. Sophie was speaking after being voted off the show and explained that she could have been more ruthless if it wasn't for the fact that she liked Sage so much.

As part of her exit interview with Parade following her elimination from “Survivor,” Sophie discussed her friendship with Sage — something that had been noted by other contestants and many viewers. She revealed that the pair bonded quickly and became close, something that may well have affected how she played the game as it meant she was not willing to necessarily put her own needs above Sage's. 

“So it's actually funny. Because if you remember that episode where Jawan goes home, I am kind of the one who is deciding between Jawan and Sage,” she reveals. “And the reason that I chose Jawan is because I was close with Sage. I was playing a little bit with my heart, not gonna lie. I had a closer relationship with Sage, and she also had proven to trust me and clued me in on things and really had my back. And so that's why I was like, ‘I have to save her now.'”

However, Sophie admitted this may have been a problem as it meant that Sage was particularly upset by what she saw as a betrayal when Sophie voted to eliminate Jawan — the other person that Sage had developed a strong friendship with. 

She said, “And in retrospect, maybe I should have just voted her out and stuck with Jawan. Because, in doing so, because we had that close bond, in breaking her trust, it was so much worse. Whereas I feel like, if I betrayed Jawan, we didn't have as much capital in our relationship. And so it might not have hurt us badly.”

The animosity that arose from the Jawan elimination wasn't enough to permanently damage the friendship between Sophie and Sage. Speaking about the relationship the pair now share since filming for the reality series ended, Sophie explained that they are “great now.” She also discussed how interesting it is to watch Sage play “Survivor” so well from the audience's perspective.

“It's been so fun getting to watch her game on TV, because she is playing such an amazing strategic game,” says Sophie. “And I think because she really dances to the beat of her own drum, you can almost forget how strategic she is. I mean, we saw it with, ‘Just tell them I'm farting. We're not talking strategy.'” 

She continued, “And so that's been lovely to see. But Sage and I are good. I had to do a little bit more damage control when we all were back in the States. But I'm so grateful to have gotten to play the game with her. I mean, kudos to her. She really spearheaded ‘Operation Kick Sophie to the Curb.'”

Title: No Funeral Planned for HGTV's Frank Cozzolino: His Daughter Explains Why
Description:
Thousands of HGTV fans have shared their condolences with the family and colleagues of Frank Cozzolino, who appeared for more than two decades on Mike Holmes' popular shows, including “Holmes on Homes” and “Holmes Family Rescue,” before his death at age 56 on December 4, 2025. 

Cozzolino's family and close friends are treasuring the memories from all who knew or knew of him rather than holding a funeral, according to the electrician's daughter, Filomena Cozzolino. 

In a social media post on December 6, she explained, “For all of those who'd like to pay their respects, he did not wish to have a funeral. Rather, he wanted people to focus on the great times they shared with him.” 

Filomena continued, “His life, and the lives of his loved ones, was enhanced by organ donation; we can take a moment to honour him by donating to organ transplant research, cancer research, or signing up for organ donation. This way, we may continue to bring others a second, or third, chance at life.” 

Cozzolino, a Canadian contractor who ran his own business in Toronto, Solutions Electrical & Maintenance, also became close friends with Holmes when he began appearing on his shows, beginning with the very first episode of “Holmes on Homes.” 

Cozzolino underwent a liver transplant in August 2017, which he wrote in an Instagram post felt like a “second chance at life.” His liver disease was an occasional topic on Holmes' shows, including an episode in which his team helped to renovate Cozzolino's home in 2022, according to Deadline. 

In her December 6 post, Filomena explained that his doctors had discovered his liver disease returned in early 2025 and that he became the “grateful recipient of a second transplant in July 2025.”

She went on to say that “there were many post-operation complications, and he conquered each new battle, until he was diagnosed with lymphoma. Ever the fighter, he never gave up. He deliberated and decided that he would push through; he'd beaten the odds up to this point, he thought ‘the world isn't getting rid of me this easily.'”

“Although he lost his battle in the late evening of December 4, 2025,” she continued, “my dad pushed the boundaries of what many of his medical team, friends, and family thought possible.”

According to Cozzolino's obituary, he was survived by his longtime partner Lisa, and his two daughters, Filomena and Alexandria. Holmes considered him a dear friend and said in a post on December 9 that he was “devastated” to lose him. 

His kids and fellow HGTV co-stars, Mike Holmes Jr. and Sherry Holmes, also issued social media statements, expressing how much they'll miss Cozzolino. Sherry called him 

In a statement issued by HGTV on December 10, per Deadline, the network said, “We are deeply saddened to hear of Frank Cozzolino's passing. Frank was an exceptional craftsman whose kindness, integrity and unwavering dedication touched every project and every person he encountered.”

Fans and friends have left tributes to Cozzolino across social media, including on Holmes' posts about him. One wrote on his YouTube video about the late electrician, “Omg ….. not Frank!….. heartbreaking news. I'm so sorry, Mike. I know he turned into a friend and then more like family over the years. He's the most honest electrician I've ever seen. Rip Frank.”

“Holmes Family Rescue” is expected to return on HGTV in 2026; it's not clear if Cozzolino was able to film any episodes for the next season before his death.

Title: Erin & Ben Napier's Show Moving Forward After Tragedy
Description:
The show must go on. When a fire ripped through the new boutique hotel that Erin and Ben Napier helped their best friends restore, the HGTV stars thought the series they'd filmed about the renovated hotel might never air.

But on December 10, 2025 — nearly four months after the devastating blaze — the couple told USA Today a version of the spinoff show will air on HGTV, after all. 

When a fire broke out at The Heirloom on August 26, the 30-room boutique hotel had just begun taking reservations amid the news that HGTV was filming a new show about the property's restoration, called “Home Town: Inn This Together.” But hours after the blaze tore through the hotel, Erin wrote on social media that she wasn't sure “you'll ever get to see this @hgtv show now.”

Restoring an old building in downtown Laurel and turning it into a hotel was a project the Napiers had been quietly working on, supporting their dear friends and business partners — Jim and Mallorie Rasberry (Jim is Erin's cousin, and Mallorie is her longtime bestie) and Josh Nowell. 

“This was their baby,” Napier told USA Today. “To watch them give their all − and I really mean give their all to create this masterpiece − and then to watch it burn together, was devastating.”

“The episodes are going to air,” Ben said of the spinoff, which will air sometime in 2026. 

The group huddled outside the hotel, Erin shared in an Instagram post that night, writing, “We held each other and watched it burning while the brave fire fighters from the Laurel FD worked for hours to get it under control. Today feels like a funeral.”  

“But I know these people,” she continued. “They won't give up here. I don't know what will happen next or if you'll ever get to see this @hgtv show now. I don't know much of anything. Pray for my friends and family, please. It is hard to explain how this reverberates through our town and its progress in many ways. But I know God has a plan for this setback. He always knows the way, even when we don't.” 

Indeed, the group has been working diligently to pick up the pieces after the devastating fire. In late September, they shared an Instagram video of the wreckage and vowed to rebuild.  

Meanwhile, season 10 of the Napiers' primary show, “Home Town,” premieres on HGTV on January 4.

Title: Guy Fieri Stands His Ground on One Hotly Debated Cooking Question
Description:
Guy Fieri has never been shy about speaking his mind, but even longtime fans were surprised to learn there is one kitchen question that pushes him toward confrontation. In a recent video shared by the Food Network, Fieri responded to a series of rapid-fire culinary debates and stopped cold when asked whether cooks should ever use pre-minced garlic.

“Okay, you want to fight?” he said in the Instagram clip.

The exchange offered more than a joke. It revealed how fiercely the “Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives” host protects what he sees as the fundamentals of good cooking. The garlic debate served as the clearest example of his belief that technique matters and shortcuts undermine the heart of the craft.

Fieri ran through several cooking questions in the video. According to the video, he said he does not wash chicken, and he told viewers not to add oil to boiling pasta water. He confirmed that he rinses rice before cooking it and explained that he maintains his cast-iron cookware with water and scraping instead of soap.

Another question prompted an even more animated response. When asked if breaking spaghetti before boiling it was acceptable, Fieri paused and jokingly mimed a punch to show where he stood.

The garlic question, though, drew the strongest reaction. Fieri did not offer a detailed explanation in the clip, but his tone made clear that he sees pre-minced garlic as a step too far from the integrity of fresh ingredients. His reaction echoed a long-running theme in his public cooking philosophy: flavor starts with technique, and technique starts with doing the work.

The garlic moment came only days after Fieri gave another set of candid opinions in a separate Food Network holiday video. This time, he weighed in on holiday dinners and did not hesitate when asked what he considers the most overrated part of festive meals.

“All the desserts. What is up with that?” he said, adding that hosts should focus on appetizers and the main course instead of offering elaborate sweets.

In the same video, Fieri said he would rather guests arrive slightly late than early so he can finish cooking in peace. He also said he prefers artificial Christmas trees because they are easier to manage during the busy season.

Fieri's comments resonated partly because they blended humor with conviction. Fans often celebrate his larger-than-life personality, but clips like these highlight the seriousness beneath the jokes. He may tease about “starting a fight,” yet the sentiment reflects his long-standing commitment to cooking with intention.

For Fieri, flavor begins long before food hits the pan. It begins with the choices cooks make. And if one of those choices involves a jar of pre-minced garlic, he is ready to speak up every single time.

Title: Japanese Breakfast's Michelle Zauner on Her ‘Materialists' Song, Favorite Rom-Coms, and Stalled ‘Crying in H Mart' Film
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Celine Song‘s throwback-to-the-1990s romantic dramedy “Materialists” premiered way back at the top of summer 2025. (A different time, am I right?) But the A24 release, which stars Dakota Johnson as a matchmaker torn between working-class ex-boyfriend Chris Evans and suave finance bro Pedro Pascal, is back in the conversation thanks to the Oscar race. And specifically, it's vying for placement among the Best Original Song shortlist being announced next weekend, for Japanese Breakfast's “My Baby (Got Nothing at All).”

As a refresher — with mild “Materialists” spoilers ahead — the song plays over the end credits as Lucy (Johnson) and John (Evans) tie the knot in Manhattan's city hall, in the same room where perfunctory marriages take place every day and also where Song and her husband, Justin Kuritzkes, had their nuptials. Depending on how empty or full the glass is feeling at that point, and whether you believe Lucy and John's relationship can survive their disparate views on money, you can read the film‘s final scene as hopeful or hopeless. And Japanese Breakfast's “My Baby,” penned by lead vocalist Michelle Zauner, is the perfect catchy bop to accompany that poetic ambiguity.

 








Related Stories ‘The Mysterious Gaze of the Flamingo' Review: Chile's Oscar Submission Is a Tender Western Pastiche About the Origins of Hate ‘The Moment' Trailer: Charli XCX Skewers Brat Summer and Jokes About Cocaine in Sundance-Bound Satire 

Grammy-nominated East Coast-originated indie band Japanese Breakfast started spinning lovelorn tales in 2013. Since then, the Korean-born singer lead singer has lost her mom, married her boyfriend, and wrote a book about it all called “Crying in H Mart.” (A film adaptation set up at MGM is currently on pause, and now without the originally attached Will Sharpe as director.) She's also released four albums with Japanese Breakfast, including the band's latest, “For Melancholy Brunettes (& Sad Women).” Speaking to IndieWire, Zauner said that writing “My Baby” proved an upbeat catharsis compared to crafting the somber sounds that make up that 10-track album.

 










Below, we discuss the writing process for “My Baby,” how Zauner's own romantic experiences connect to the movie, and the status of her “Crying in H Mart” movie.

This interview has been edited for length.

IndieWire: You and Celine Song are both millennials who aren't that many years apart, and both bring a Korean-American background to your work. Was “Materialists” your first meeting?

Michelle Zauner: Surprisingly, we never met up until this movie collaboration happened. I was a fan, and I think she had heard of my music before…. We first met on Zoom, and then I don't think we met in person until after the song [“My Baby (Got Nothing at All)”] was recorded, and the movie was put together, and she came to a show of mine. 

[She was] one of those people that you get along with right away. I have, many occasions in my life, met people that are millennials and Korean and artists, and it doesn't always happen. Just because all those things align doesn't mean you'll necessarily vibe. So it was really nice getting to meet her, because I think she's so brilliant, and also such a warm and fun person to get to hang out with.

Did you see the full script or a full cut of the movie before writing the song?

The movie was pretty much done. I was sent a screener, and it was the first time that I've ever watched a screener or gotten to be a part of a film process in this way. [Celine] was looking for a song for the end credits, which I thought was especially appealing because it kind of gave you full reign. You didn't really have to squeeze into a moment, and you weren't really responsible for pushing a viewer to feel a specific way beyond this almost summarizing feeling. It felt like I had more freedom getting to be a part of the end credit song than, maybe, if I had to insert myself into a really intense moment. 

 










I got to watch the full movie, and I really loved it. I just thought it was so modern, and it was something that I felt like was really missing from the zeitgeist. I just felt like it encompassed a lot of things that I've been thinking about as a 30-year-old woman, watching my friends go on dates and rue the current landscape.

You've been with the same person for over a decade. Does the long-term nature of your relationship color the way you look at this movie, or romantic comedies in general?

I don't want to speak out of turn, but I married very young. I married when I was 25, and it was kind of a rush situation where my mom — I wrote about this in my book [“Crying at H Mart”] — was sick and was going to die. [My boyfriend and I] had been dating for about a year and a half … We threw together a wedding in three weeks, and my mom was there, and it was a really beautiful ceremony. I was always kind of like, “Oh, we'll just get divorced if it doesn't work out. It's not a big deal.” We've been married for 11 years, and [originally] neither one of us had jobs, really, or any kind of financial security. And later, I learned that Celine and her husband actually married quite young as well, and that was something I was thinking a lot about, because my friends who are in their 30s and dating now, the things that they look out for [are] very different than the things that I considered when I was that age. My husband lived in a warehouse with, like, six roommates and had no windows and slept on a mattress on the ground, and at the time, I was just like, “He's hot, and that's all that matters.” And it worked out, because I feel like we really grew up together, and the things that what would be red flags for me now are things that we kind of learned together.

 










So I think that what Celine has to say about that kind of perspective — that this desire to not give up hope for falling in love [not be] something that's only for the wealthy class — we shouldn't be so pessimistic about it.

Did you write this song from the perspective of Dakota Johnson's character?

I'm thinking of myself in Lucy's position and her choice at the end of the film, and to me, the lyrics are this chorus of people giving her advice. “You should find someone who has a company.” “You should find someone who makes a living.” “You should find someone who makes some figures.” They're kind of cute ways of turning those pieces of advice on their head [and saying,] “My partner doesn't have these things, but he offers something else.”

Is there anything here that feels like a remnant of past work, or even a shred of an idea that you put a pin in from the past? This song is in the running for the Best Original Song Oscar, and one of the requirements is that songs have to be written anew for the film. 

[The song] came in a really great time, where I was just gearing up for my album cycle — this current album cycle “For Melancholy Brunettes (& Sad Women)” — and I had just written all these really melancholic, ethereal, contemplative, somber songs. I was excited to write something a bit more upbeat, something that was like a classic love song and felt good, after being, like, a very serious, type A artist about my record and, in the same breath, [wanting] to make something that I felt was clever and timeless. The only thing that carried over was I was using a lot of open D tuning on the last record, and that maybe my guitar had already been in that tuning and made its way onto the song.

 










I saw your Letterboxd four favorites. “Melancholia” was on there — not exactly a romantic comedy, but a personal favorite. What are your favorite romantic comedies or romantic dramedies?

If I were to do four romantic comedies, which I would say is my favorite genre … I love all Nora Ephron movies, but “When Harry Met Sally” I've maybe seen, like, 5,000 times. I really want to have a “When Harry Met Sally” party where we have apple pie à la mode with strawberry ice cream on the side and Katz's Deli, and we all wear the white sweater that Billy Crystal wore and play charades.

“Exorcist baby!”

I recently rewatched “Pride and Prejudice” with [Matthew Macfadyen]. (Celine is operating in that realm, to me — like a modern Austen tale.) That movie is so well done. And obviously, Ang Lee's “Sense and Sensibility” is so great. And I love anything Julia Roberts. I love “Notting Hill”; it's one of the few romantic comedies that you see largely from the male point of view. And “My Best Friend's Wedding” I love, too.

Do you play “My Baby” now as part of setlists unrelated to “Materialists” FYC performances?

Yeah, we do. I actually really love it. 

I think that people like the song, so it's so fun to perform, and sits in a sweet spot in my register. I think, because there were not a ton of upbeat songs on [my recent] record, it's been fun to incorporate it into the sets. I'm really proud of what we made.

 










It sounds like you spent a year writing a script for “Crying in H Mart,” an adaptation of your very personal memoir about watching your mother die. I'm sorry to hear the project is on hold, but did you learn anything about yourself or your own stamina in the process?

I learned a lot about the industry that makes a lot of sense to me now. It was a tough project because it was so personal, and this industry requires so much collaboration in order to make something happen. It costs so much money, and there's so much process involved and so many people involved. You cannot make a movie on your own in any way. That was interesting for me to witness and was challenging in ways that I expected and didn't expect.

Are you wanting it to move forward, or feeling like you can set it down for now?

I'm optimistic about it happening someday. I'm not interested in rushing; it's such a precious, personal story that I'd rather not make a movie than [make] a bad movie. And I love everyone that is involved and was involved in [helping it get] as far as it got, and would love to do it with the same people. But we're not in the midst of making it right now.

You're writing another book, though.

I'm currently writing my second book. It's also a memoir; I think it may be my last memoir. It's about the year I spent last year in Korea, learning the Korean language and going to school and living abroad and documenting that time.

Title: KP Skywalka: I Tried to Tell You Album Review
Description:
8.4

 Best New Music 

Genre:

Rap

Label:

Beat the Odds LLC / NEWWRLD

Reviewed:

December 11, 2025

KP Skywalka begins the standout “Hell or Not,” the penultimate track of I Tried to Tell You, by singing, “[What] am I supposed to do?” His voice cuts in and out like a hazy recollection and Erykah Badu's sampled voice plays alongside, like he's riding in the backseat of his mom's sedan. The southeast DC rapper's brief trip down memory lane with the '90s R&B of his youth gives way to asking his little homie if he's “ready to war up,” laughing at some rapper bragging about “guns that he never shot,” and getting wistful for the days when it was “just noodles and Spam.” Quasi-apocalyptic visions of his Beltway landscape rub up against tender musings, spilling out of KP with a possessed, drill-tinged flow. You get the sense that these moments are closer in his mind than they appear in the rearview.

KP's adherence to the DMV's blossoming drill style—punching in with breathless, rambling raps that spare no detail—has become more established even as he's tinkered with the boundaries of the subgenre. This year's 4 Tha Freakas and 2023's Rhythm N Bip approached X-rated, applying groovy R&B flips to player anthems that teemed with sordid accounts of spitting in her mouth and fucking every which way. Even when KP follows fellow scene members like Skino and SlimeGetEm toward more standard Free Car Music themes—morbid corner stories over ominously bouncy beats, like on 2023's Getting Right the EP—he remains an extremely adept narrator. His lines burst with personality, even if they can feel a tad one-note for long stretches (lyrical predictability being a common trap for this strain of drill).

I Tried to Tell You avoids monotony by bouncing around KP's musical styles and personal history with limitless energy. His roving narration isn't limited by regional rap convention: weaving together familial, emotional, and hustling memories in a production landscape that draws from the various roots of Black soul music tradition, the album is a proof of concept that demonstrates what it means to experiment in earnest within the DMV underground scene.

The 20-song tracklist, a departure from 4 Tha Freakas' brief onslaught of ballads, allows KP room to amble. His beat selection (with production also provided by Turn Me Up Pro, Yoyotheproducer, and Tavaras Jordan) feels as though it's meant to stitch together soulful touchstones of his childhood: crooning along to the warbling H-Town sample on opener “Industry” on the way to a Wizards game, or reaching into the record cabinet and choosing Anita Baker's voice to frame his soothing, plugg-infused linkup with 10kdunkin, “Nuntoloose.” DC's go-go tradition looms large in the way the drums titter underneath a funky, Wayne Shorter-esque saxophone sample on “VPN” as KP melds his delivery to the rhythm. The varied production coaxes out distinct styles: the angelic choral arrangement on “Streets Sing to Me” slows his raps to a crawl, while “A Drop Out” feels like a TLC 12" (maybe something off FanMail) warped by heat and heartbreak.

Most often KP's nimble references and turns of phrase arrive under the cover of the hostile drill flow that's overtaken this kind of DMV street rap. But his style is steeped in the slow-crawl storytelling of the Southern rappers he listened to growing up, and the diligent way he constructs his world on I Tried to Tell You evokes Pimp C's meticulous autobiography on The Sweet James Jones Stories: Picture KP and his cousin speeding through red lights and goading each other to shoot up the deli (“Scared Like Steele”), or making it up and down the Northeast Corridor before sunrise (“Latenight”). He's got a hundred variations on the word “bip,” tossing it everywhere like parsley on an IG chef's channel. Sometimes his musings are routine (“I'm blowing up but I'm stuck in a warzone/Fuck is the bros on, let's get on Warzone”), or sound morbidly mundane (“I can talk about murder in music because I really done it”). But the continual tweaks to his diction allow simple phrases to escape tedium.

The tension between KP's inner sensitivity and the hardened shell he's formed to survive is the emotional crux of I Tried to Tell You. At the outset of “See My Wrongs,” his romantic optimism is potent: “Know it's some good in the nigga hope that she sees it,” he raps with clarity, before recounting step-by-step how he helped another friend reach his dreams of being a killer in the streets. On “Made It Out,” he remembers a successful headshot, then stutters over his words as he wonders if the pain of losing his own homies made him “d-depressing.” Even when paranoia and melancholy tinge his reflections on fatherhood and family in “Heaven Sing,” there's still room to fondly remember the neighborhood girl who popped out with a belly ring in the summertime. When his words contradict like this, KP often switches to a higher, sing-song register, as if he wants his truths to carry for miles—no matter if they line up on paper.

What keeps I Tried To Tell You alive and breathing is how clearly KP understands that thematic conventions are made to be broken, and how willing he is to follow his instincts. Gun ad-libs flow out of him in the background of “Itty” like he's arguing with himself on the track. He treats his collaboration with Skrilla like an away game, skating over calypso drums and sharing custody of their region's favorite word; he invites DC's Skino and Philly's Lil Hawa to take the reins for extended moments in the spotlight. When he returns to the player-anthem bars about stealing dudes' girls, it doesn't sound like a labored effort to maintain 4 Tha Freakas' momentum, but like he's recounting something that happened right before he waltzed into the studio. Each nugget is evidence that Free Car Music can retain its toughness and bite without sacrificing ingenuity and individual soul. I'm left hung up on KP's final words on closer “Pockets Flat,” which come after some musings on stacking cash and stomping opps: “Ain't see grandma in two months, like she want see my face,” he raps, with his voice edited to sound like it's somewhere off in the distance. The tightrope act goes on.

Title: JJJJJerome Ellis: Vesper Sparrow Album Review
Description:
8.0

Genre:

Electronic

Label:

Shelter Press

Reviewed:

December 11, 2025

Vesper Sparrow opens with a declaration: “A stutter c-c-can be a musical instrument.” This was an epiphany for the Grenadian-Jamaican-American composer and artist JJJJJerome Ellis, and became the guiding principle of their work. At an early age, Ellis found liberation in the fluid sounds of the saxophone; speaking, by contrast, caused shame and discomfort. Ellis' stutter manifests as a glottal block, an involuntary pause in their speech. Eventually, Ellis learned to see these pauses as a source of possibility. In a social context, a block can lead to confusion or embarrassment, but in a musical setting that same pause can dilate time, create moments of intimacy, and open avenues for improvisation. Now, Ellis follows their stutter like a path through the wilderness, trusting it like true intuition.

Ellis calls their glottal blocks “clearings,” as in a suddenly open space in the middle of a forest path. Historically, clearings were places where enslaved African Americans could congregate and pray. Ellis explored the complex relationships between Blackness, speech dysfluency, and music on their excellent 2021 debut The Clearing (and in a research paper of the same name). That album—didactic yet inventive, intensely emotional while remaining rigorously intellectual—was like a manuscript bursting with ideas, brought to life with hip-hop, R&B, and jazz. Vesper Sparrow, Ellis' follow-up, is more focused but just as deep, a prose poem rather than a dissertation. Their focus now is on time: how a stutter can suspend time for both speaker and listener, and how bridging that gap can forge new connections.

Vesper Sparrow has a fraction of The Clearing's word count, allowing Ellis to show, rather than tell, how their theory informs their practice. Still, a bit of explanation is in order. As in Alvin Lucier's “I Am Sitting In A Room,” another piece that turns a stutter into an instrument, Ellis begins the four-part “Evensong” by telling us how they made it. “I made this music at MacDowell artist residency in spring of 2019. I'm listening to it as I speak,” they say. “The music you're hearing now I created using a process called [pause] granular synthesis.” The pause is filled with music: ecstatic saxophone, hammered dulcimer, and drifting vocals. Ellis goes on to describe how they split their original recording into snippets of sound called “grains,” and the music demonstrates this by disintegrating into isolated sounds that fall like raindrops at the beginning of a storm. On “Evensong, Part 2” Ellis gathers these grains and rearranges them into a flood—the sax now sailing over waves of distortion—then continues: “When I make a piece of music, the music [pause]...”

The structure of Vesper Sparrow, and the crux of Ellis' thesis, hinges on that pause. Like the earlier pause, it is filled with music—but this time, the gap comprises two-thirds of the album. The four parts of “Evensong” are interrupted—no, suspended—by two versions of the hymn “His Eye Is on the Sparrow,” in recognition of Ellis' upbringing in his reverend grandfather's church. On the title track, sparse piano accompanies Ellis' soulful voice as he sings, “Why should I feel discouraged?/And why should the shadows come?” Slowly, tentatively, a saxophone joins, fluttering like sparrows' wings. On “Savannah Sparrow,” Ellis takes the same hymn and stretches it into a 16-minute pipe organ drone in memory of their grandmother, who played the organ in church; over it, they play a powerful sax solo. Ellis has said that they stutter on the sax, too, which may account for their gripping presence with the instrument; each breath, each click of the keys, feels as patient and considered as a loving conversation.

“...[pause] passes through me. It's a seed I plant. The seed grows, mostly unobserved,” Ellis says at the beginning of “Evensong, Part 3,” resuming their earlier thought. It's a simple trick, but it feels like time travelling: The journey that we've taken through Ellis' religious past is contained in a single glottal block. This is the possibility of the clearing as a space for meditation, connection, and prayer. Ellis finishes his explanation of granular synthesis by describing “grains” as pollen, though his grains are carried “not by wind … but by the silence that authorizes and protects all music.” If the structure of Vesper Sparrow is based on a block, so too is the method of “Evensong.” Granular synthesis separates tiny bits of sound with silence, like myriad clearings that introduce infinite possibilities. “Evensong, Part 4” celebrates these possibilities with piano, dulcimer, vocals, flute, and saxophone playing in exuberant loops, savoring every repetition.

Ellis often tells a story to illustrate the potential of a clearing: Once, after they had finished ordering at a restaurant, they blocked when asked to give their name. The cashier simply waited, unbothered, encouraging, caring. Maybe the employee didn't realize it, but they were performing together, and Ellis' instrument was their stutter. Vesper Sparrow shows what can happen in such moments: The world slows down, opens up, and becomes a bit more beautiful.

Title: Watch Charli XCX Hide Inside a Giant Lighter in New The Moment Trailer
Description:
The official trailer for The Moment, the new A24 movie starring and conceived by Charli XCX, is here. Following last month's teaser, the trailer further explores the movie's light satire of the Brat era, in which Charli clings to reason amid a whirlwind of bad advice and unscrupulous interlopers. Among them are a goofball live-show director played by Alexander Skarsgård—at one point, he instructs her to hide inside a giant lighter while the crew maintains a wide perimeter—as well as various friends, suits, and influencers, played by the likes of Kylie Jenner, Rachel Sennott, Rosanna Arquette, Kate Berlant, Hailey Benton Gates, and Jamie Demetriou. Watch the trailer below.

Directed by Aidan Zamiri, The Moment is one of three Charli XCX films showing at Sundance Film Festival, which runs from from January 22 to February 1, 2026. (The other two are Olivia Wilde's The Gallerist and Gregg Araki's I Want Your Sex.) The Moment hits theaters everywhere on January 30.
