Title: Alien Contact Tour brings extraterrestrial encounters to St. George
Description:
Reporter











St. George might see some out-of-this-world visitors this Sunday as aliens are set to make an appearance at Pioneer Park.

“If you like the vision of universal peace, universal love and universal well-being, then you are going to enjoy this event,” said Alien Contact event coordinator and founder Rupert Guy. “It is all about trying to make the world a better place and trying to live in harmony with all conscious beings throughout the universe.”

Guy said the Alien Contact event will begin with humans making friends before any extraterrestrial introductions. Although the main program starts at 7 p.m., guests can arrive at 6 p.m. to mingle in a friendly orbit. Guy said the goal is to bring people together in friendship regardless of differences, including religious beliefs or political convictions.

The evening will move into a guided astral projection meditation designed to help participants reach out to any visiting beings and offer an open invitation for contact.

Attendees at the Alien Contact event gather in hopes of encountering extraterrestrial beings, location and date not specified.

“What typically happens is people start feeling the presence of these beings around us on the ground,” he said. “Psychic people will see them standing around trying to support what we are doing. Occasionally, we will see alien craft in the sky flying above us.”

St. George is one stop on what Guy said will be a more than five-month Alien Friendship Contact Tour across the country. The tour began Nov. 30 in Bakersfield, California, and is scheduled to continue through Fresno and Sacramento before making six stops in Nevada, including Area 51.

After St. George, the route moves to Page, then travels through New Mexico, Oklahoma, Missouri, Indianapolis, Kentucky, Tennessee, Georgia and Alabama, with a tentative finale planned in Arkansas.

He planned the tour to cover as much of the United States as possible, estimating it would span 40-45 states. St. George naturally fit into the route between Sedona, Area 51 and other locations he considers key stops on the journey.

A possible extraterrestrial craft is captured over an Alien Contact gathering, location and date not specified.

Cosmic encounters

At the first two events of his 2025 tour, Guy said attendees reported seeing black streaks darting through the air nearby. Around the same time, a member of his online group described receiving a “download” from alien beings and began noticing similar black streaks in her vision. Intrigued by the phenomenon, Guy attempted to connect with the streaks to discover who or what they might be.

“We always reach out to beings with love in our hearts and friendly intentions,” he said. “It turned out that these black streaks identified themselves as positive, friendly beings who had a message for us.”

Guy said that when participants communicated telepathically with the beings and asked for a message, three people in three different locations reported the same vision: Guy standing in a forest clearing, surrounded by a large group of nonhuman beings. He said the consistency of the visions across separate observers serves as logical proof of a genuine psychic telepathic message.

He said he does not know when or where the vision will manifest, but it seems to serve as a notification or invitation to the forest clearing gathering. He hopes the meeting will take place during his tour.

Rupert Guy, founder of Alien Contact, leads a U.S. tour designed to help humans connect with each other and extraterrestrial beings, location and date not specified.

Guy said everyone can experience paranormal or alien encounters, but an open mind is key. The beings cannot force contact and will retreat if someone is not ready, though they can telepathically and empathically sense a person's mind and heart.

How the cosmos called

Growing up in England, Guy said he realized at an early age that he was more empathetic than most. He cared so deeply for people, animals and the planet that he could not watch the news because it was too painful. 

Determined to make a difference, he felt he first needed to understand reality. If God were real, he wanted God on his side. If aliens were real, he wanted them on his side or anyone working to protect the planet.

He began exploring aliens, paranormal phenomena and religions alongside scientific study. He attended the University of Leicester in England, earning a first-class honors degree in Physics with Space Science and Technology and later pursued advanced work in astrophysics and research.

“I ended up with a pretty clear picture of scientific realities, but also alien, paranormal and spiritual realities,” he said. “I now teach people about these realities and try to elevate people's understanding of reality, but also morality to alien levels.”

Rupert Guy, founder of Alien Contact, leads a U.S. tour designed to help humans connect with each other and extraterrestrial beings, location and date not specified.

Guy is a retired space scientist and science teacher who calls California home but travels the world. He founded the group Alien Contact five years ago and has led about 10 tours since then. This is his first time hosting an event in St. George.

“I have spent my entire life reaching out to aliens and spirits in peace, trying to establish friendly, constructive relationships with them,” he said.

Join the Alien Contact event at Pioneer Park on Sunday, Dec. 14, from 7-9 p.m. Early birds can arrive at 6 p.m. to mingle in a friendship circle before the cosmic adventure begins.

Dress warmly and bring a yoga mat or tarp to sit or lie on. Be ready for a short walk from the parking area to the contact spot, where the night's extraterrestrial encounters will unfold. For more details and tickets, visit the event page and prepare for a night that's truly out of this world.

Reporter

Title: This Classic Supernatural Episode Is the Scariest 44 Minutes of Winchester Lore
Description:
"Saving people, hunting things, the family business" is a quote that has become synonymous with Supernatural, but no other season encapsulates this feeling like Season 1 of Supernatural does. Before the horror show fell into overarching storylines that lasted seasons, it was known for its snappy monster-of-the-week format, where Sam and Dean Winchester hunted down a different demon in every episode and actually saved countless lives while doing so.

20 years after the release of the first season, it remains the most iconic outing of the CW show. While the Winchesters were tracking down paranormal absurdities across the country, they were also rebuilding a bond that they had lost for many years. In Season 1, Episode 5, "Bloody Mary," Supernatural was at its finest, terrifying viewers with a familiar monster, while also giving them much-needed emotional payoff.

 The legend of Bloody Mary is one that has been worn thin over the past few decades, especially through email forwards that simplify it to the point where it ceases to be scary. According to the lore, if one faces a mirror and says "Bloody Mary" thrice, a woman will kill them instantly through the reflective surface. Supernatural decided to add layers to this old horror story, and the result was 44 minutes of pure terror. 

The episode begins as the scariest stories do: at a slumber party where three teen girls are playing sleepover games. Charlie and Jill dare Lilly to go to the bathroom mirror and say "Bloody Mary," which she does, but nothing happens. Lilly's father, Steven, asks the girls to keep the noise down, but when he goes back to his bedroom, he's haunted by a horrific figure in the mirror. With his eyes liquefied and his head filled with blood, Steven dies a sudden and agonizing death.

As Sam and Dean descend on Toledo, Ohio, for another monster-of-the-week case, Jill decides to repeat the phrase "Bloody Mary" jokingly into a mirror, and soon sees the same dark figure and suffers the same agonizing death as Steven. Trying to find a pattern, Sam and Dean inspect the mirrors that the two victims died in front of, and found the names of Steven's wife and a little boy who had died in a hit-and-run case, whose car details matched Jill's.

Sam and Dean find a vengeful spirit named Mary Worthington, who had been killed in front of a large mirror when she was a teenager, and when her murder was not solved, she started attacking those whom she thought had secretly killed other people, the way she had been. The mirror found its way to Toledo, and the brothers then worked towards saving Charlie, who was being followed by Mary because she once had a boyfriend who died by suicide when she left him. Finally, the brothers made Mary face herself in a mirror for the crimes she had committed, which led to the spirit finally dying.

 Supernatural could have taken the easy route and had Mary kill the people who summoned her, but writers Eric Kripke, Ron Milbauer, and Terri Hughes Burton chose to add layers to a story that had been done to death. They refreshed it by giving Mary an origin story; she used to be a young girl whose life was ended in an untimely manner. So, she made it her afterlife's purpose to avenge those who had killed people and gotten away with it.

Mary Worthington's crusade for justice matched Sam Winchester's own guilt about his girlfriend, Jessica's death. Jessica had died in the same way his mother had, and Sam felt responsible because he had dreamed about her death for weeks, but had done nothing to prevent it. Throughout "Bloody Mary," Dean tried to get Sam to talk to him about the nightmares he was having, and to relieve him of his guilt because he could not have prevented Jessica's death in any way, but the show decided to tackle it through the monster of the week instead.

Mary Worthington's spirit tried to attack Sam, and he, too, bled from his eyes, but the key lay in Sam finally trusting himself and his brother that he did not kill anyone. This horror masterpiece of a Supernatural episode had viewers jumping at every turn, but it also had the sweet sentimentality that formed the bedrock of the show. Sam had to process his grief and guilt about Jessica's death, and this lethal spirit helped to do just that, eventually drawing Dean and Sam closer than ever before.



We want to hear from you! Share your opinions in the thread below and remember to keep it respectful.

Title: Where Alien Abductions Happen Most And Least in America
Description:
The Jersey Shore's Hit Music Channel

New Jersey has received good news about an odd topic. We are among the states where you are least likely to get abducted by an alien.

We don't know if you believe in UFOs or aliens, but we do know that no matter where you land on the topic, the news is that abductions from outer space are low in New Jersey.

While New Jersey residents are not the safest from getting an unwanted trip on an alien spaceship, we are among the top 5 safest states, according to the New York Post.

I'm not going to lie. You can count me among the people who think there is something out there, so this news is a big relief to me.

There are actual statistics to back this up as well. Or at least the odds of your chance of getting abducted.

Read More: A Terrifying Haunted New Jersey Road

In New Jersey, the chance of being taken by an alien is 1 per 3086, which isn't exactly low enough odds in my mind.

The safest state from alien abduction is Louisiana, followed by Mississippi, Alabama, and Virginia.

The state where you are most likely to be taken by an alien is California, where the odds are 1 in 1075.

I don't know if this information will help you sleep better or keep you up all night, but good luck.

Gallery Credit: Lou Russo

Gallery Credit: Lou Russo

Title: Idaho child thought she'd been kidnapped by aliens
Description:
This article contains spoilers for Netflix's Abducted in Plain Sight.

Jan Broberg was just a young child when she thought she'd been taken by aliens.

She'd been living, what appeared to the outside world, a relatively normal life with her family in 1970s Idaho, but that all began to change when she was abducted by supposed aliens.

The story all started when a man named Robert Berchtold came into Jan and her parents' lives. Robert, also known as "B," moved in next door to the Brobergs and quickly befriended them. However, he would go on to kidnap Jan, not once, but twice, leading her to believe that the first time, it was caused by aliens.

When Robert moved in across from the Brobergs, he soon befriended Jan's parents before he turned his sights on the young girl, whom he started to spend a lot of time with one-on-one. The Brobergs were extremely religious and were easily fooled by Robert, who trapped them in a web of complicity and shame.

This devastating tale of crime and deceit is covered in Netflix's Abducted in Plain Sight, which includes testimony from both Jan and her parents, who attempt to explain how they allowed Robert to kidnap their daughter, not once, but twice.

The 91-minute documentary explains how Jan believed she was abducted by aliens when Robert took her for the first time because he played a cassette that told the 12-year-old she had to "procreate" with him as part of a secret alien mission.

During this abduction in 1974, Robert drugged Jan and drove her to Mexico, where he held her captive for five weeks, brainwashing her into believing she was half-alien and had a mission to save her home planet by having a child with him before she turned 16.

To keep her quiet, he further told her that if she informed her parents about what happened, then they'd be harmed. It was also reported that he assaulted the 12-year-old 200 times during her time in captivity.

However, despite Robert being arrested in Mexico for abducting Jan, he didn't face very much jail time. This is because he blackmailed her parents, as he'd had separate sexual encounters with them both, so they signed a document saying they'd given Robert permission to take their daughter. He only served 10 days in jail for the kidnapping.

Two years after the first abduction in 1976, Robert took Jan again. In the period between the two abductions, he continued to stay in contact with Jan and her family, even at points sleeping in the child's bed as part of a false type of "therapy." He also continued to use the alien narrative to keep his claws in Jan.

When Robert abducted Jan for the second time, he enrolled the then 14-year-old in a Catholic boarding school under a fake name and posed as a CIA agent.

Jan's parents waited two weeks before calling the police, supposedly because they were concerned about how the public would react. The FBI would then get involved, monitoring Robert, and eventually rescuing Jan.

However, even though Robert was charged with the kidnapping, he would be acquitted due to a "mental defect." He was then sentenced to a few months in a mental health facility and was released after five months.

Years later, though, after Jan had been granted a lifetime restraining order against Robert, he would be found guilty of aggravated assault and possession of a firearm after attacking members of Bikers Against Child Abuse (BACA) who were at one of Jan's events. Robert died by suicide in 2005 before the sentencing hearing could take place.

Abducted in Plain Sight is available to stream on Netflix.

If you are a survivor of sexual assault, you can call the National Sexual Assault Hotline (1-800-656-4673) or visit its website to receive confidential support.

Title: Ex-Psychic's Dire Warning About ‘Wicked' Movie
Description:
Share This article

Jenn Nizza, an ex-psychic who now runs a ministry urging people to flee the occult, is warning that “witchcraft is real” and is encouraging people not to watch “Wicked: For Good,” the new sequel to the wildly popular film “Wicked.”

 



Nizza, host of the “Ex-Psychic Saved Podcast,” told parents the movie “has a witchcraft influence” and is “romanticizing” the issue.

“This is very concerning to me, especially the indoctrination of the demonic targeting the youth,” she said. “This is my Christian perspective on this.”

Nizza has widely documented her decades in the occult, working as a psychic and medium before encountering Christ at the age of 37.

She said that experience has forced her to pause when it comes to projects like “Wicked.”

“As somebody who lived in the life of the occult and the New Age for many years … this film is playing on the sensitivities of many people, suggesting there should be some compassion for the bad witch,” she said, noting that the film also “suggests that there can be good witchcraft.”

This teaching is “dangerous,” according to Nizza.

“I just want to speak into this because I've been there,” Nizza said. “This movie is showing witchcraft. … Witchcraft involves invoking demons … it doesn't matter if you call yourself a good witch or a bad witch; it's condemned by God.”

Watch Nizza explain:

Title: Metroid Prime 4: Beyond
Description:
As you begin to explore Viewros in Metroid Prime 4: Beyond, Samus will pick up a few new abilities along the way to help you on your journey. Each one is specifically tied to points in the story, so while you won't be able to unlock any of them earlier than is intended, it's still worth knowing when to expect them and what they do.

Shortly after arriving on Viewros, Samus will acquire the Psychic Crystal, which ultimately gives her the ability to use Psychic Abilities, the first of which includes the Psychic Visor. That said, Psychic Abilities aren't the only things that Samus can unlock, as various upgrades for both her and Vi-O-La will also be available throughout the game.

 While you don't really need to worry about missing out on any of the abilities and upgrades in Metroid Prime 4, you should understand what each one does in full, as most of these will be necessary to progress at certain points and will also aid in solving puzzles throughout the game.

This table covers Psychic Abilities, Suit Upgrades, Weapon Upgrades, and even Vi-O-La, so for a full breakdown of everything, please see below:

Ability/Upgrade

Explanation

When It Unlocks

Vi-O-La Suit

Samus's main suit for Metroid Prime 4, which allows her to use Vi-O-La.

Unlocked the first time you visit the Volt Forge. This simultaneously unlocks Vi-O-La as well.

Vi-O-La

Samus's bike throughout Metroid Prime 4. Also features Projectiles and a Boost that can be followed up by a damaging Power Slide.

Unlocked while visiting the Volt Forge for the first time, at the same time as the Vi-O-La Suit, as the bike cannot be used without it.

Vi-O-La IC Suit

Upgrade that adds heat-resistance to Samus' Vi-O-La suit, which also unlocks the matching upgrade for Vi-O-La.

You'll be able to see this upgrade in the Volt Forge the first time you visit, but you won't be able to unlock it until you have the Psychic Boost Ball. Once you have that, return to the Volt Forge to upgrade your suit.

Vi-O-La IC

Upgrade that adds heat-resistant features to Vi-O-La. This upgrade will automatically activate when needed.

Automatically unlocked when Samus upgrades her suit with the Vi-O-La IC Suit upgrade.

Fire Shot (Normal/Charged/Super)

Normal — Deals elemental fire damage, which also causes a burn, where enemies take continuous damage. Consumes one Shot Ammo.

 Charged — A more powerful Fire Shot with multiple projectiles. Consumes three Shot Ammo.

 Super — The most powerful version of your Fire Shot that fires even more projectiles than the Charged Shot. Consumes fifteen Shot Ammo.

Normal — Unlocked by acquiring the Fire Chip early on in the Flare Pool and taking it back to MacKenzie at Fury Green.

 Charged/Super — Both the Charged and Super shots are unlocked by completing the Ladder of Thought Shrine and the Rings of Stone Shrine. Whichever one you complete first will unlock the Charge, and whichever one you complete second will unlock the Super. The Ladder of Thought Shrine is the most easily accessible, and thus recommended first.

Ice Shot (Normal/Charged/Super)

Normal — Deals elemental ice damage, which also causes enemies to freeze. The amount of time spent frozen is enemy-dependent. Consumes one Shot Ammo.

 Charged — A more powerful Ice Shot with multiple projectiles that can ricochet off surfaces to hit enemies. It also causes enemies to freeze for a longer duration. Consumes three Shot Ammo.

 Super — The most powerful version of your Ice Shot that fires even more projectiles than the Charged Shot, all of which can ricochet. Once again, this also increases the duration for which enemies are frozen. Consumes ten Shot Ammo.

Normal — Unlocked by acquiring the Ice Chip in the Ice Belt and taking it back to MacKenzie at Fury Green. Note that the chip is in a container that needs to be dropped by the Loading Crane at the start of the area, but you won't be able to get the Ice Chip until you've defeated Keratos. So you'll need to come back for it.

 Charged/Super — Both the Charged and Super shots are unlocked by completing the Floating Path Shrine and the Source of Spring Shrine. Whichever one you complete first will unlock the Charge, and whichever one you complete second will unlock the Super. The Source of Spring Shrine is the most easily accessible, and thus recommended first.

Thunder Shot* (Normal/Charged/Super)

Normal — Deals elemental electrical damage that shocks enemies. This can also be used to power various devices. Consumes one Shot Ammo.

 Charged — A more powerful Thunder Shot that has a chain lightning effect, where it will bounce between enemies. Consumes five Shot Ammo.

 Super — The most powerful version of your Thunder Shot that fires a consistent electric current for several seconds. Consumes twenty Shot Ammo.

Normal — After unlocking the Psychic Grapple, return to Volt Forge and use it to cross the collapsed catwalk before heading to the bottom of Tower 1. You'll find the Thunder Chip in the Power Core, but just be wary that this will trigger a boss fight.

 Charged/Super — Both the Charged and Super shots are unlocked by completing the Rings of Thunder Shrine and the Falling Labyrinth Shrine. Whichever one you complete first will unlock the Charge, and whichever one you complete second will unlock the Super. The Falling Labyrinth Shrine is the most easily accessible, and thus recommended first.

Control Beam

A beam that can be controlled by Samus' mind, which allows you to guide it to a specific location. Can only be activated while using the Psychic Visor. This is mainly used for puzzles, but can be used to pinpoint specific weak points on enemies as well.

Unlocked early on in Fury Green while completing a puzzle.

Missile Launcher

Gives Samus the ability to launch missiles that can lock on to and track enemies. Consumes one Missile Ammo.

Unlocked shortly after meeting Mackenzie in Fury Green.

Super Missile

An upgraded and more powerful version of the normal Missile Launcher. Consumes five Missile Ammo.

Unlocked after completing a puzzle with VUE-995 in the Great Mines.

Psychic Bomb

Gives Samus the ability to drop up to three bombs. If you charge the bomb, it will create a Mote that Samus can control. The Psychic Bomb can only be used in Morph Ball mode.

Unlocked immediately after defeating Carvex in the Garden of Remembrance in Fury Green.

Psychic Power Bomb

Upgrade for the Psychic Bomb that deals more damage and can be used to solve puzzles.

Unlocked immediately after defeating the boss of The Great Mines, Omega Griever.

Psychic Boost Ball

Upgrade for the Morph Ball that allows Samus to trigger short bursts of high-speed rolling. Can also be used to power devices and damage enemies.

Unlocked immediately after defeating Keratos in the Lamorn Laboratory in the Ice Belt.

Psychic Spider Ball

Morph Ball upgrade that gives the Morph Ball the ability to magnetize to magnetic tracks. Can also be used to hang from a Tether Node or ride a Psychic Ball Track that was spawned using the Psychic Visor.

Found in the Ancient Temple in the Ice Belt, but only after unlocking the Thunder Shot.

Psychic Visor

A scan visor that allows Samus to scan things in the world and interact with Psychic Energy to solve puzzles or find collectibles.

Unlocked at the start of the game, in Chrono Tower, after the purple Psychic Crystal is placed in Samus' forehead.

Psychic Boots

Gives Samus the ability to perform a double jump, also known as a Space Jump, and gives her the ability to stand on Psychic Platforms that are spawned using the Psychic Visor.

Even though you'll come across Psychic Platforms a little earlier, you won't gain access to the Psychic Boots that allow you to walk on them until you defeat Xelios in the Volt Forge, not long after you receive the Vi-O-La Suit.

Psychic Glove

Gives Samus the ability to control Motes and move other psychic objects when paired with the Psychic Visor.

Found in the middle of the Arboreal Chapel in the Fury Green. You'll need this upgrade to progress, so you can't miss it, and it's unlocked not long after the initial tutorial sequence.

Psychic Grapple

Gives Samus the ability to utilize grappling hooks and cross over large gaps or reach high points.

Unlocked after defeating the boss of the Flare Pool, Phenoros.

Psychic Lasso

Creates a ropelike strand of psychic energy that can be used to pull an object towards you. Can only be used on objects that are compatible. Using your Psychic Visor can reveal hidden lasso points.

Found in the Bio-Labs level of the Ice Belt. You'll need to complete a puzzle there to unlock the ability.

Legacy Suit

The final suit upgrade in the game. The Legacy Suit gives Samus the ability to utilize a protective Psychic Barrier that will nullify the effects of most incoming attacks. After a set amount of time, the barrier will fade. However, the rate at which it fades depends on the amount of damage absorbed by it. The barrier will also damage enemies that come into contact with it.

Unlocked after visiting the Altar of Legacy in Fury Green when 100 percent of the Green Energy Crystals have been collected.

* While all elemental shots have their own use, Thunder Shot is the most easily integrated into your standard firing rotation due to its quick ability to charge and the speed at which you can transition from the Thunder Shot to your normal Psychic Beam.

If you want to listen to music or avoid having to complete 100 percent of your scans, you might want to check out the Metroid Prime 4: Beyond amiibos.

Title: Erika Kirk has one word for Candace Owens, who's been peddling conspiracy theories about Charlie Kirk
Description:
Watch CBS News


December 11, 2025 / 11:41 AM EST
            / CBS News
          

Erika Kirk has one word for Candace Owens, who has been peddling conspiracy theories about her late husband, Charlie Kirk: "Stop."

In a town hall set to air Saturday at 8 p.m. ET, CBS News editor-in-chief Bari Weiss asked Charlie Kirk's widow what she wants to say to Owens and others who are making unfounded claims about his assassination:

"Stop. That's it. That's all I have to say. Stop."

Owens used to work for Turning Point USA, the conservative youth organization founded by Charlie Kirk. The two were generally considered friends, with Owens describing their relationship as akin to that of a "brother and sister." 

A day after his assassination in September, she posted a nearly 25-minute video, saying she wanted him to be remembered for his career and ideas. But in the months since, Owens has pushed conspiracy theories about his murder and made unfounded fraud allegations about the finances at Turning Point, which Erika Kirk now runs.

The Treasury Department sent Erika Kirk a letter last week, confirming that none of the tax-exempt entities she oversees are under investigation by the IRS. "The IRS is able to provide this type of information upon request by the taxpayer. And in this case, it's hideous that malicious lies and smears obligated [Erika Kirk] to make the request," a senior Treasury official told CBS News.

Erika Kirk talks more about her husband, her journey through faith and grief, and the state of the American right in a CBS News town hall. It will air just days after Charlie Kirk's book, "Stop, in the Name of God: Why Honoring the Sabbath Will Transform Your Life," was posthumously released.

Watch the one-hour town hall Saturday at 8 p.m. ET/CT on CBS. An extended version of the conversation will air on CBS News 24/7 on Sunday at 9 a.m., 3 p.m., 8 p.m. and 11 p.m. ET, and will be available on CBS News' YouTube channel.

Title: A different 'cold case': Frozen solid, she was nearly declared dead. Then, she was given a chance to live
Description:
Sponsored By

ADVERTISEMENT

ADVERTISEMENT

LENGBY, Minn. — Wally Nelson opened his front door on the morning of Dec. 20, 1990 and saw a 19-year-old woman lying in the snow, just feet from his home. 

“Her face was ghost-like,” Nelson told The Associated Press in 1990. “I figured she was dead.”

ADVERTISEMENT

Nelson recognized the young woman: Jean Hilliard, a family friend. Unbeknownst to Nelson, her vehicle veered into the ditch, miles away. 

"I had my parents' car, and I was just upset that I'd slid off the road," Hilliard, who now goes by Jean Vig, told Forum News Service. "I was hoping the car was okay. So even that night, the cold didn't really bother me or make me afraid. I was frustrated more than anything."

A cold snap had hit Minnesota that evening, with temperatures dipping below 22 degrees Fahrenheit, according to newspaper accounts from the time.

Vig knew she was close to the Nelson home, which belonged to family friend.  So, in the frigid Minnesota night, she attempted the trek to his house. 

"I knew he lived down the road and had a pickup truck, so he could pull me out," Vig said. 

Yet as Vig set off on foot — dressed in cowboy boots, jeans and a snowmobile jacket — she began to realize Nelson's home was farther away than she anticipated. 

"It was a little country road, and there were little hills. So I'd get over a little hill thinking his place was going to be there, and then I'd get there and it wouldn't be."

ADVERTISEMENT

She kept going — and she nearly made it. 

"The last thing I remember was being at the top of the hill and seeing his house," Vig said. 

Tracks in the snow told the rest of the story. 

“You could see where she had crawled the last few feet before collapsing,” Nelson told the Associated Press. “You could also see where she had fallen three or four times from the mailbox, one-eighth of a mile down the road.”

The tracks kept going, indicating she crawled across his yard and up onto his doorstop, where she collapsed. 

She spent roughly six to seven hours passed out in the below zero temperatures. 

Hilliard's body was frozen stiff when Nelson picked her up and placed her — diagonally — in the backseat of his car that morning. 

ADVERTISEMENT

He raced to the hospital, hoping for a miracle.

When they arrived at the hospital, her temperature didn't register on a standard medical thermometer. They couldn't find a pulse. Medical staff also weren't able to insert any needles as her skin remained frozen. Her eyes weren't responding to light, either.

They would have considered her deceased — if they hadn't heard the faint gurgling sounds that resembled a form of breathing. 

"They couldn't get a pulse right away, but then they heard a gurgle like through my nose and determined that I was somehow breathing," Vig said.

Hospital staff wrapped Hilliard's body with water-based heating pads. Within two to three hours, she began to respond to treatment.

Hilliard wasn't in the clear, though. Her breaths per minute — one to two — were far below the normal rate of 12 to 20 per minute.

As the day progressed, she gradually began to wake up. By that afternoon, her cognitive ability was back to normal. 

ADVERTISEMENT

When awake, Vig could see the black blisters on her toes. It was a concerning sign for her medical team. Amputation was a possible scenario. 

Yet as Vig later learned, just hours before she was fully awake, her doctors informed her family that if she did make it, she could have to have both legs amputated, too. 

At the time the family was told this, her legs were showing signs of detrimental frostbite.

Just as her legs regained their fleshy tone and normal function, her toes cleared up as well. 

She walked away from the near-death experience without any long-term side effects.

Life for the 19-year-old was different when she was discharged from the hospital. 

"I got calls from reporters and from magazines, so it didn't really go back to normal for quite some time." 

ADVERTISEMENT

It didn't take long for her story to spread throughout the country. Newspapers from Fargo to California carried the story, with headlines that read, “Woman survives six-hour exposure to sub-zero weather” and “Woman comes to life from out of the cold.”

Her recovery was considered a medical mystery — and miracle. 

“I can't explain why she's alive. She was frozen stiff, literally,” her physician, Dr. George Sather, M.D. told the Associated Press. “It's a miracle.”

Vig doesn't disagree. 

Just as news coverage reached all corners of the country, Vig learned that she had been at the center of many prayer group and churches, who took an active interest in her recovery. 

"I do think it was a miracle," she said. "I found out later just how far the prayer chain spread. So, I had a lot of people praying for me."

She isn't certain why her life was spared, and she's content with not knowing or understanding. 

ADVERTISEMENT

"It's not something I really dwell on. I mean it could be something as simple as my kids or my grandkids ... something special in their life."

Vig went on to live a relatively normal life. 

She had three daughters, who she raised on a farm before moving to the northern suburbs of the Twin Cities in the mid-1990s. 

It was during that time when her story resurfaced. 

In 1996, her story was featured on Unsolved Mysteries. At the time, the television show was among the most popular in the nation. 

Vig was happy with the way the television show portrayed her story. 

And just as it was when she was 19 years old, people began to show interest in her story. 

Vig is happy to answer questions and share her experiences — especially around Christmas. 

"It happened just before Christmas. So that was Dec. 20," Vig said. "People are looking for miracles and the good that has happened." 

There are a few questions Vig commonly fields regarding her survival, one of which addresses any possible health issues she has from her time as a human ice cube. 

The only thing she cant think of? She now prefers cold weather over the heat. 

"I can tolerate the cold better than than the heat," she said. "So, I'm not I'm not one of those that wants to go to Florida or Arizona in the winter."

ADVERTISEMENT

ADVERTISEMENT

Title: Goldman Sachs leads investment in software delivery startup Harness at $5.5 billion valuation
Description:
In this article

Almost nine years ago, Jyoti Bansal sold AppDynamics to Cisco for $3.7 billion just as the software startup was set to go public. 

Bansal's latest venture, Harness, is now worth substantially more than that, after raking in $200 million in fresh capital at a $5.5 billion valuation in a funding round led by Goldman Sachs.

Harness' technology helps companies manage and monitor code that's produced with the help of artificial intelligence, making sure it doesn't break, create security vulnerabilities or trigger cost overruns. It's a compliment to the so-called vibe coding trend that's taken off with the boom in generative AI. 

In recent months, venture capitalists have poured money into startups such as Cursor, Lovable and most recently Kilo Code that sell subscriptions for tools for directing AI models to write and update software. Harness' software draws on models from Anthropic and OpenAI.

Earlier this year, Bansal bolstered Harness' cybersecurity chops by merging the startup with Traceable, another company he co-founded. The combined company, based in San Francisco, has a total of about 1,300 employees.

Harness is on track to exceed its goal of more than $250 million in annualized revenue, growing more than 50% year over year, Bansal said. That makes it larger than AppDynamics at the time it was acquired by Cisco. 

Bansal is aiming for a different outcome this time. 

"I'm a believer that at the right market timing, we want to operate as a public company, so we can build for the long term," Bansal said. 

In addition to the funding round, Harness is also planning a $40 million tender offer to provide some liquidity to long-standing employees.
